Hi Derek, the type of neuron you cite is indeed a leaky neuron, but 
there =
are at least two types of leaky neurons that can be 
implemented, one of wh=
ich is the "leaky integrate-and-fire" neuron, 
which is a spiking neuron as=
 you say.

However, there is also a non-spiking version of leaky neurons ca=
lled 
a "leaky integrator" neuron, which uses rate-encoding (i.e. the 
neur=
ons output a number interpreted as a rate just like ANNs we are 
used to). =
 The leaky integrator is probably easier to implement and 
also more effici=
ent, although because it is a higher-level neural 
model than leaky integra=
te-and-fire, it may not capture all the 
neural phenomena as the more low-l=
evel model, such as spike-time 
synchronization.

Leaky integrator networks=
 are often instead called "Continuous Time 
Recurrent Neural Networks" or C=
TRNNs.  So it's useful to search for 
that in addition to "leaky integrator=
 neuron."  Floreano has a good 
paper on them with implementation equations=
.  My dissertation also 
contains leaky integrator equations in its discuss=
ion section in the 
back.  There is also actually a modified version of my =
NEAT code in 
the files section of this group by Tyler Streeter that evolve=
s leaky 
integrator networks from a few years ago.  (He used it to evolve 
=
walking gaits)

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <djames@...=
> wrote:
>
> I just have a general neural network question:
> 
> Is there a=
 general term for artificial neurons that have residual 
output in
> the ab=
sence of new input?  I'm pretty sure that leaky integrate-and-
fire
> neuro=
ns have this property, but those are necessarily spiking 
models,
> correct=
?
> 
> So let's say at time t a neuron has a very high activation due to 
h=
igh
> input, but at time t+1 it is receiving zero input, but it's 
activati=
on is
> now a percentage of its activation at the previous timestep:
> 
> x=
(t) =3D x(t) + Dx(t-1)    where D is a decay rate
> 
> Is this called a lea=
ky neuron?
> 
> Thanks,
> Derek
>
